Confession: I have never taken a Chemistry class, (In the 70's girls took "useful classes" like shorthand :) ) so a lot of this talk went way over my head. I did enjoy many of the stories, especially the ones connecting with Marie Curie, I have always had a fascination with her. 3- The best thing about belonging to Book Groups, is reading out of your comfort zone.

An excellent audible performance explaining how the periodic table came to be, interspersed with stories about the discovery of specific elements and their uses through time. I would have preferred to read a hard copy of this so I could re-read and make sense of the complexities of elements, electrons, molecular makeups, and other chemistry basics.

A grab-bag of information and stories more or less related to the periodic table of the elements. The writing is pretty good, but the chapters are general-interest magazine articles written too late for the era of the general-interest magazine, and do not benefit from being grouped together on the unlikely premise that they together form a coherent book.Still, you know, it's fine.

Funny, quirky and informative; as Goethe said, the history of science is science; and science is WEIRD (as well as petty, jealous, and obnoxious, among other things). Technical enough to be challenging and funny enough to be memorable.
A fascinating exploration of the periodic table of elements and the effect each element had on human history.
This was interesting and enlightening - chemistry, physics, and history together.

I was never very good at chemistry. It seemed to me to be a hopeless subject, full of equations that didn't make sense, where balancing the elements was considered an essential skill, where memory mattered, and where weird sounding names reacted to produce weirder compounds still. It didn't help that my family's take on chemistry was that all chemistry is physics, chemists merely handle the boring parts of physics. This all changed when I began to struggle and fail in high school, Year 11, and my parents hired a private tutor in desperation. Amit sir was gruff, down to earth and he spoke my language. Before he agreed to teach me, he sat with me for a trial class. He wanted to determine whether he could teach me at all, or not. After that first class, which I had been dreading, he got up, and told my parents that he would be fine with taking me on. Quite surprisingly, I found myself wanting to study chemistry, because this was the first lecture where I understood exactly what was going on.My dad at this point told Amit sir that chemistry has been a family disease, and sir took it as a challenge, and said "This is one disease I will cure."After that, he did whatever it took to get me to study. He would come early and play chess, he would entertain my endless questions far beyond the scope of the syllabus and he would research to answer whatever I asked. By the end of two years, of all my subjects, I scored the highest marks in chemistry.When I read this book today, I am able to appreciate and enjoy it because I understand the bones and the basics of chemistry, which would not have been possible without him. This is why I began my review with this anecdote.This book will probably be slightly dry and slow for people who have slogged through chemistry in high school, just to pass their exams. Most of those people will not make it through to the end of the book. To other people, who have had a strong base, and who enjoy learning about the stories that went into the discoveries of elements, to those people who revel in the factoids of science. This book tells the unusual stories that went into discovering the elements and the many applications of those elements and their unique nature and abilities.For me, this book rates as 4 stars, and not 3, because I'm able to appreciate and enjoy the obscure history in the discovery of the elements, but I can't in good conscience give it the same rating overall, because I know that there are many people who I would not recommend this book to.My ratings go somewhat like this:3 stars: The book was readable and I finished it comfortably, but I would not actively recommend it unless it suited someone.4 stars: I will recommend the book to most people without thinking twice.5 stars: I will force feed the book to people even if I have to tear it into tiny bits and push it down their throats.Because of this categorisation, this book sits squarely at 3 stars. There are parts of it that go into unnecessary and boring detail, but the book survives because the writer writes with intense passion, and those details are a side effect of that passion. That is something I'm happy to over look.To Summarise: Read it if you liked chemistry or if you want to know more about it. Otherwise, duck.

One of the prettiest books I have on my shelves right now is Theodore Gray's The Elements, a visual collection of all the elements that make up the physical universe. "Everything you can drop on your foot," as he says. In it, he provides wonderful pictures and descriptions of the elements that we know, arranged as they would be in the periodic table. It's a gorgeous book, one that everyone should have - especially if you have children. If you want your kids to become interested in science and investigating the world around them, you could do far worse than to have this book on your shelves.Eventually, though, they'll be old enough and canny enough to ask, "Well, how do we know all this? Where did we find these things, and how? And why are they in this order?" That's the point where you hand them The Disappearing Spoon, sit back, and let Sam Kean take over.The story of the elements, and our understanding of them, is governed just as much by personality as by p-shells, as much by competition as by charge, as much by ego as by electrons. While the elements themselves don't pay any attention to human affairs, the quest to understand the building blocks of matter have sent us to the hearts of stars, the depths of the earth and, for various reasons, Ytterby, Sweden. [1]Kean starts with how he got into the elements, with a story that would horrify modern-day parents: mercury. When he was a kid, his mother would collect the mercury from broken thermometers and keep it in a little bottle on a high shelf. If they were lucky, she would let her children play with it for a while, swirling it around and watching while this shiny liquid metal split apart and fused back together perfectly, never leaving a bit of itself behind. It was a metal that flowed like water, and it was fascinating. If he had known at that age that ancient alchemists thought there were spirits living in mercury, he would not have been surprised.Keeping an eye out for mercury, he learned that modern scientists are able to follow the expedition of Lewis and Clark using mercury. The explorers carried with them a good quantity of Dr. Benjamin Rush's Bilious Pills, a "cure" for any illness that mainly contained mercury chloride. It was vile stuff, poisoning everyone who took it, but without an FDA around to stop this kind of nonsense, Rush made plenty of money. It probably didn't hurt his credibility that he was one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence. In any case, he gave samples to the Lewis and Clark expedition, and their latrine sites can still be found today by the unusually high levels of mercury that were deposited there as the men's bodies tried to get rid of the heavy metal as quickly as possible.Mercury also taught Kean about mythology - the Roman god of communication, modeled on the Greek message-bearer. It taught him etymology - the chemical symbol for mercury is Hg, which is derived from the Latin hydragyrum, which means "silver water." It informed him on literature, especially the Mad Hatter of Alice in Wonderland, who was based on the poor crazies who used to breathe in the fumes of mercury while setting felt for their hats.This one weird, eerie element was a door into so many other topics that he figured there must be others. And so he started work on this book, a collection of histories and tales, gossip and hearsay, all centered around the 118 physical elements that make up our universe. "As we know," he writes, "90 percent of particles in the universe are hydrogen, and the other 10 percent are helium. Everything else, including six million billion billion kilos of earth, is a cosmic rounding error." Within that rounding error, though, some amazing things have been found.In the 19th century, the Russian Dimitri Mendeleev examined the common properties of different elements and was able to sort the elements in such a way that took advantage of their similarities. The violent alkalies along the far left, which will explode if given half a chance, and their cousins, the halogens on the far right, some of the most reactive elements in nature. Separating them are the noble gasses, which don't react with anything unless pushed to extremes. Without knowing about electron shells and the weird quantum things that happen on the atomic level, Mendeleev managed to put together a table so good that he was able to leave gaps in it that corresponded to elements that hadn't yet been found. And by telling the world that these gaps existed, the race to isolate and discover the elements was on.Kean's book is a great look at the way science works on a human level. How the search for high-quality porcelain led to the discovery of an entire class of elements, how Marie Curie would get into trouble by dragging her (male) colleagues into dark closets to show them how radium glowed, how nitrogen kills with kindness and lithium quiets an unsettled mind. The competition to not only find these elements but to name them and find uses for them has driven science forward in all fields, from geology to neurology, for the last two hundred years. Those 118 squares on the periodic table have driven men to travel the world, to create economic and political empires, to love, to hate, and to murder.If this kind of thing were taught in high school chemistry class, there would probably be a lot more kids interested in science as a career.The book is very readable, even if it does drift from time to time into more technical areas. One of my colleagues, who doesn't have an extensive background in science, said she was a little slowed down by talk of electron shells and quantum jumps, which I guess were not aided by Kean's elevator similes. But it did get her asking the right questions - how do we know atoms exist if we can't see them? How can we be sure that what is in this book is true? Those are the questions that Kean tries to answer in the book, but it's also the kind of book that may bring up more questions. It's "gateway science," one of those books that pulls away the cold, rational veneer of the scientist and his or her endeavors, and shows what an exciting, weird, messy and dramatic place science can be. What's more, it shows how science is deeply ingrained not only into our technology, but our language, history and politics. An understanding of science, even at an amateur level, is a wonderful way to open your eyes to the great, complex and bizarre world in which we live.-----------------------------------------------------------"We eat and breathe the periodic table; people bet and lose huge sums on it; philosophers use it to probe the meaning of science; it poisons people; it spawns wars. Between hydrogen at the top left and the man-made impossibilities lurking along the bottom, you can find bubbles, bombs, money, alchemy, petty politics, history, poison, crime, and love. Even some science."- Sam Kean, The Disappearing Spoon------------------------------------------------------------[1] The town has the distinct honor of having four elements named after it: yttrium (Y), ytterbium (Yb), terbium (Tb), and erbium (Er). What has your hometown got?

This is really interesting and well done. I enjoyed a lot of the details and anecdotes. I think at the end of the day though, I wanted more of the random anecdotes of the weird uses of some of the elements in the past, and less of the discussions on higher levels of physics and chemistry. The problem with higher level physics (less so chemistry, which I understand better), is that after a certain point it just sounds made up. I accept that it is not made up, and it is based on science, but if you don't know much about it, it's hard to latch onto some of the details, and I found myself skimming.I also think it's a touch long. It's a book of sort of randomly collected stories about the periodic table, but because the only overarching story is building the table itself, sometimes I again felt my mind drifting. I read this in fits and spurts over two weeks. It's not the kind of book you make it through in one sitting (though it did bring back any number of flashbacks on chemistry class).That said, I am delighted to learn that apparently Marie Curie used to haul male scientist colleagues into darkened closets to show them radium's glow (and associated radioactivity) with at least some regularity, and apparently on one occasion the demonstration was broken up by a colleague's suspicious spouse.2018 Reading Challenge - A microhistory

I found this book fascinating, with all of its tales regarding the periodic table and the scientists who spent their lives researching, testing and searching for the elements, and all of the anecdotes associated. The author, in turns, educated, entertained, surprised and delighted me. I want to read more of his books!

Because of the nature of the history of various elements on the table, this book felt a bit scatter-brained in scope and details. For all that, though, it was an excellent read and I learned a lot about various elements. It helps to have a least some basic knowledge of chemistry, but it's pretty easy to skim over anything you feel might be overly technical.

Checking off one from my far too many (just kidding...one can never have too many books to read) Small Stacks of Found Books that I kept setting aside for others, this is in one word a delight! Mr. Kean has done something marvelous here: making the periodic table fun and accessible! For science geeks (and professionals) it always has been, but for those less inclined...this is great.He says in his Introduction that from the one element mercury, he "learned history, etymology, alchemy, mythology, literature, poison forensics, and psychology." He also learned physics and chemistry, clearly, because it's all through this book, and politics that sometimes had play in the field. And Kean conveys the history and concepts in the best mystery page-turner style, along with humor and sagacity. Even if you know the history and concepts, the chemistry and physics (I'm not a neophyte to either), I suspect you'll learn something or somethings.Kean talks of the discoveries of the elements (and many of the gaffes), the origins of the table, the blanks and how they were filled. He delves into the biological interactions of some of the elements, from poisons to medicines, and how some elements mimic others, causing all kinds of havoc on the biological front. There is the politics of the Nobel prizes, the currency of elements, art and literature of elements. Something as seemingly simple as the Parker 51 pen gets copy time here, as the nibs were made of "durable ruthenium", "an element little better than scarp until then."Near absolute zero, bubble chambers, "Tools of Ridiculous Precision"...there is so much information here. I couldn't begin to summarize with any justice. I'll share one nugget to illustrate Kean's keen science. (Forgive, please!) There's a chapter on toxicity of exposure (or ingestion) and a GREAT observation I flagged. Great to me, anyway. In talking about William Crookes, his "lapse into spiritualism", and succumbing to "pathological science", Kean explains pathological science:In explaining what pathological science is, it's best to clear up any misconceptions about that loaded word, "pathological," and explain up front what pathological is not. It's not fraud, since the adherents of a pathological science believe they're right - if only everyone else could see it.(And here's the gem...It's not pseudoscience, like Freudianism and Marxism, fields that poach on the imprimatur of science yet shun the rigors of the scientific method.Love it! Pseudoscience! I've been saying so for years!It's also not politicized science, like Lysenkoism, where people swear allegiance to a false science because of threats or a skewed ideology. Finally, it's not general clinical madness or merely deranged belief. It's a particular madness, a meticulous and scientifically informed delusion. Pathological scientists pick out a marginal and unlikely phenomenon that appeals to them for whatever reason and bring all their scientific acumen to proving its existence.Kean says that a pathological science's "believers use the ambiguity about evidence as evidence - claiming that scientists don't know everything and therefore there's room for my pet theory, too."Read it. Highly recommended.

Anyone with an interest in science, whether you are just curious or science is your life's work, should read this book.I admit, I thought this book would be more of a curiosity, a sit down and leaf through it kind of book. Instead, I found it utterly engrossing on many different levels.I really enjoyed the stories-- the stories of people and personalities, of discoveries that were searched for over many years and those that accidentally fell into place, of friendships and partnerships and rivalries.I also enjoyed the science itself. I consider myself to be a scientifically inclined, so this isn't a surprise. I've got a solid background in chemistry and physics, even if I haven't thought about it in years, so the concepts weren't new. The first few chapters are much heavier on the science, lighter on the stories. If they get to be too much, flip further in and read a chapter. If that's more to your taste, then just skim through the rest of the first section. I do think this book is accessible to those with minimal scientific background-- I think my daughter learned enough in 5th grade science about atomic structure to understand most of the stories.I also think there is enough there for those that have been dedicated to science their entire lives. In this case, the names will be familiar, but I think the stories will be new, and they will even more fully appreciate following the paths in the history of the various elements.I'm thinking Christmas presents here, and I'm strongly considering buying some copies for my daughter's school.

This was an impulse buy- a symptom of my late in life discovery of science history. I never have had the single-minded concentration for pure science, but I loooove a good story. And this book is full of better than good stories. Plus, Kean is punny-- a clever word smith who never misses a chance for word play. E.g. In describing Ernest Rutherford's attempt to date Earth's creation: "Thorium then begets radium by spitting out another alpha particle. Radium begets radon with yet another, and radon begets polonium, and polonium begets stable lead."Kean also deserves credit for bringing the role of women in from the margins and even pokes a little fun at the latent sexism of a couple of scientists who couldn't figure out how they missed fission: "Fission escaped us, although it was called specifically to our attention by Ida Naddock, who sent us an article in which she clearly indicated the possibility... The reason for our blindness is not clear."Notables:- A teenager who built a nuclear reactor in his shed-Hiding gold from Nazis in plain sight-Legit origins of the story of King Midas-Gandhi's vendetta with iodine-Sir Isaac Newton's revenge on a counterfeiting heckler- public disembowlment-The mainstreaming of my granddaddy's metal- aluminum

The sensationalistic and often crude writing style marks Mr. Kean as the journalist that he is. Hence, the writing is sometimes more agenda driven and biased than one likes to see in a science text. With the emphasis on historical anecdotes, however, this is more forgivable. His ability to so frequently associate chemistry to sex is an interesting, but hardly commendable, talent. I would personally mark the swearing level as moderate (or whatever word one would use to mean “somewhere between mild and severe”).Despite my lack of enthusiasm for the style, I learned a ton from this book. One of the things I like most about it is its ability to show how chemistry links in with other sciences. It shows many cool relationships. Most high school science courses mistakenly take each subject alone and disassociate it from any other. This book would pretty effectively combat that failing. Hence, I think it would work very well as supplemental reading for a high school or college chemistry course. I would, of course, be sure to mention the above caveats to anyone I recommended this book to.

This book rocked my world. I mostly daydreamed through chemistry class in high school, and would rather have knocked my head against a wall repetitively than studied it in college - so needless to say, I learned a lot from Kean's insights.I won't lie, the theoretical chemistry and quantum mechanics went about ten miles over my head, but I'm friggin' in love with all the history and mystery surrounding the elements. I feel like I finally have a grip on what makes up our world. Not to mention how awesome it is to understand some of the great scientific discoveries made over the centuries: how we've determined the Earth's age, the steps of radioactive decay, potential silicon-based alien life, etc. This is the perfect book for intelligent people who didn't major in chemistry, but still want to understand and appreciate our periodic table. Kean doesn't come across as a pompous ass or talk down to the reader--he hits that sweet spot in between. Both informative and entertaining.Read on, fellow nerds!

Every college chemistry teacher should read this book! I've taken so many college/university-level chemistry classes, yet author Sam Kean is the first person who managed to explain the periodic table in a way that makes sense and is memorable without a lot of memorization. I now understand the way the elements relate to each other better than I ever have, even though my last chemistry class was over 14 years ago. The anecdotes about the different elements and the men and women who discovered them are entertaining, but the periodic table is the real star of this book. There are a few small sections that may be over the head of anyone who isn't familiar the behavior of electrons, for example, but it's easy enough to just skim over those pages to get back to the anecdotes. This is an excellent book for the armchair scientist, trivia enthusiast, history buff, or anyone who enjoys understanding more about the world around them. The endnotes alone are wonderfully entertaining.

I'm going to say that I feel like Mr.Kean took everything he knew about the periodic table of elements and vomited it into this book. I really enjoy the tidbits of information but I dislike to organizational format. Mr. Kean walks you through the table by introducing you elements related in properties. I personally would have preferred a chronological narrative. I felt like the players were coming in and out of the story- the table evolved and devolved. In one chapter is the late 90s race for heavy metals and the next chapter is pre-table with a different community of chemists. In spite of the jumpy time table, I think it's worth the read. I found it very thought provoking as a relative stranger to chemistry. However, don't expect a book that reads like a novel.

Got this out of the library a while back, mainly for my wife who teaches chemistry, as a general book for her to maybe recommend to her students.Overall is is quite good. It is a science book that is written in a style that could be described as conversational. It has some humour in it, and lots of facts, anecdotes and tales of the the individuals who made the science of chemistry what it is today. One of the most fascinating is the discovery of a natural nuclear power station that has been running for 1.7 billion years.I have only given four stars as I feel that the book Periodic Tales, is much better at explaining the elements.

Who knew science was about love, war and practical jokes like disappearing spoons? As an engineer who once considered majoring in chemistry, I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Sometimes science can be rather dry, but learning the twists and turns of its history really makes it interesting. I always wondered why my European coworkers always referred to "aluminum" as "aluminium". Question now answered! This book is full of fun stories and anecdotes that I've been having fun sharing with my husband. He can't wait to read the book himself.

I think I will buy this for my little chemist as she goes off to college :)Other than chap. 16 which was a bit over my head, this was an enjoyable, informative read for a layperson. I have always been intrigued by the elegance of math and science. Through anecdotes, Sam Kean give the reader a glimpse at Marie Curie's work, the disappearing gallium spoon, the stories of zirconia and aluminum, the mentos dropped in cola experiment, etc.

I wish this book had existed when I took high school chemistry. These interesting "real world" stories about the elements we don't notice in our day to day lives could have helped jump start learning so much information. This book is rather like a series of short stories, easy to dip into and to read a bit here and a little more later. One complaint is that the footnotes, which are interesting and worth reading, are at the back of the book rather than at the bottom of the page.

Caleb and I listened to this together, and we both loved it. however this book isn't for everyone; if you hated high school chemistry, don't bother. But if you almost let your husband convince you to name your firstborn "Molybdenum" (Molly for short), you will love this book, as did I. (We named her Alaina instead. I think it was for the best.)The ending dragged on a bit, but overall it was a great chemistry refresher with lots of fascinating stories from history intertwined.
